[SYNTAX]: Abrupt transition between historical and artistic discussions (e.g., shift from Thomas Becket to Boucher's art style)
[LEXICON]: Overly complex vocabulary may hinder smooth reading for non-specialists (e.g., "contumacy", "moulding of his technique")
[GRAMMAR]: Minor punctuation inconsistencies (e.g., missing Oxford commas in lists)

[STRUCTURE]: Non-chronological and thematic jumps (e.g., historical event, artistic style, philosophical quote, prehistoric Canterbury)
[TRANSITION]: Lack of clear connections between paragraphs (e.g., from Reynolds to Von Eicken to Canterbury's history)
[CLARITY]: Assumed knowledge in multiple domains (art, history, philosophy) without introduction

[SYNTAX]: Complex sentence structures may impede smooth reading in some areas.
[LEXICON]: Occasional use of less common vocabulary (e.g., "sultifying", "sultry atmosphere") might slow comprehension for some readers.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from discussing Bahá’u’lláh to historical events in Canterbury without clear connection.
[STRUCTURE]: Non-linear narrative jumps between different time periods and topics (e.g., from 597 to modern implications for the Church of England).
